Name of faculty: Science Department: Biotechnology Unnamed: 0 Unnamed: 1  Unnamed: 2  Unnamed: 3
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         Program: B.Sc. Microbiology Sem 5               Type: DSE-9       SE-9        NaN         NaN         NaN
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 Subject:Molecular Biology                  olecular        NaN     iology         NaN         NaN
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           Credit: 04 + 02  Total learning hours: 60        NaN        NaN         NaN         NaN
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       Course Description:\rInculcate strong fundamentals on basic and advanced molecular biology concepts. This is a\rvital course for the graduate students which provides enhanced knowledge on replication,\rtranscription and translation with their regulatory aspects and also includes content\rimparting knowledge about protein maturation and post translational modifications.                       NaN        NaN        NaN         NaN         NaN
Student Learning Outcome: After completion of this course the students will be able to\runderstand the central dogma of molecular biology. Further the syllabus will mainly\relaborate the following points\r●Covers the concept of genetic codes and their features. It explains more about the\rtranscription occurring in Bacteria, Eukaryotes and Archaea.\r●Emphasizes on synthesis of proteins, how are these proteins modeled to give a\rcorrect form. It also explains further about protein maturation and how these\rproteins are targeted to their destination on secretion.\r●Highlights about the levels of regulation involved in RNA and protein synthesis. It\rgives information on processes like splicing and RNA editing. It explains about the\rrole of ubiquitylation and chaperon mediated protein folding\r●Provides information about regulation of genes in viruses additionally. It talks more\rabout global regulatory systems.                       NaN        NaN        NaN         NaN         NaN

Name of faculty: Science Department: Biotechnology Unnamed: 0
                                            Program: B.Sc. Sem 5 Type: DSC-10:        NaN
                                           Subject: Fundamentals of Immunology        NaN
                                      Credit: 04 + 02 Total learning hours: 60        NaN
                                                           Course description:        NaN
    The paper imparts the fundamental aspects of the protective defence system        NaN
       mounted by the host against the foreign threat/invading harmful agents.         It
            encompasses various components and approaches employed by the host        NaN
   defence system to provide protective state – immunity against such invading        NaN
harmful agents-pathogens. It discusses the applications that are devised using        NaN
     these components and approaches including diagnosis, treatments, therapy,        NaN
      prophylaxis etc. and also elucidate the abnormalities/diseases/disorders        NaN
                                  arising on account of immune malfunctioning.        NaN
                                                     Student learning outcome:        NaN
                             On completion of course students will be able to:        NaN
            ● Understand the immune system, its components and their action to        NaN
                              provide the protective state to the host system.        NaN
       ● Explain the significance of functioning of innate and adaptive immune        NaN
                           systems in eradicating pathogens or harmful agents.        NaN
         ● Explain how the protective immune system once developed in the host        NaN
     lasts for lifetime and actively works in removing the antigen efficiently        NaN
                                                    at every moment of attack.        NaN
     ● Describe interactions of the immune components (Ag-Ab/cell) in in vitro        NaN
                                                       and in vivo conditions.        NaN
        ● Apply these interactions for diagnostic, prognostic purposes i.e. as        NaN
       diagnostic techniques, vaccines, treatments and control of diseases and        NaN
                                                                    disorders.        NaN
    ● Learn about the various conditions a host may get exposed to if the host        NaN
               immune system does not work in a regulated controlled manner by        NaN
                               studying immune related diseases and disorders.        NaN

Name of faculty: Science    Department: Chemistry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Program: B.Sc. Microbiology Sem 5             Type: SEC -3
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Subject: Instrumentation and Techniques                      NaN
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Credit: 04 + 02 Total learning hours: 60
                                                                                                                                                                                              Course description:\rThis course is concerned with the theory and practice of instrumental methods for the separation,\ridentification and quantitative analysis.                      NaN
Student learning outcome:\rUpon completion of this course, students will:\rIntegrate a fundamental understanding of the underlining principles.\rUse key instrumental techniques for separation and analysis.\rDistinguish between qualitative and quantitative measurements and be able to effectively\rcompare and critically select methods for analyses.                      NaN

Name of faculty: Sciences Department: Microbiology
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Program: B.Sc. Microbiology Sem 5              Type: DSE-5
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             Subject: Haematology and Blood Banking                      NaN
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         Credit: 02 Total learning hours: 30
                                                                                                                                         Course description:\rThis is an advanced course in Hematology and Blood Banking for B.Sc students. This course\ris designed to highlight the important principles and concepts of haematological and blood\rbanking and thereby emphasising on theoretical as well practical knowledge in preparation,\rhandling and testing of various diagnostic criteria related to it.                      NaN
Student learning outcome:\rStudents will be benefited by understanding the basic concepts ofvarious\rroutes of blood collection, mechanism of blood coagulation and various types\rof anticoagulant used in vitro\rStudents will be conceptualized about the Haemoglobin, various types of\ranemia, and clinical diagnosis related to blood coagulation.\rStudents will acquire the understanding about blood banking by learning ABO\rand Rhtyping,variouscompatibilitytestsandsignificanceinblood\rtransfusion                      NaN
